logical.description: True if both expr1 and expr2 are true.
True if either expr1 or expr2 are true.

binary arithmetic.description: Subtract the second operand from the first operand.
Divide the first operand by the second operand.
Raise the first operand to the power of the second operand.
Divide the first operand by the second operand and yield the remainder portion.

relational.description: True if a is less than b.
True if a is greater than b.
True if a is equal to b. Please use **two** equal signs for equality comparison.
True if a is not equal to b.
True if a is less than or equal to b.
True if a is greater than or equal to b.
True if a matches the pattern specified by b.
True if a is equal to any of the values in the list.

array operations.description: This expression gets the first element in array bbox. For example, 'bbox[0] < 50' evaluates to true if the value of bbox[0] is less than 50.
This expression evaluates to true if array bbox contains element 100.
This expression evaluates to true if int_array contains all elements 1, 2, and 3.
This expression evaluates to true if var_array contains any element of 'a', 'b', and 'c'.
This expression evaluates to true if int_array contains exactly 4 elements.

use cases.description: Filter the results with table_name equal to 'chunks' and column_name equal to 'text_content'.
Filter the results with table_name equal to 'chunks' and primary_key equal to any of the values in the list ['123', '456', '789'].

use cases.example: (text like 'RAG%' or text like '%RAG') and text not like '%rag%'
use cases.description: For text modality, filter results with text content containing 'RAG' but not containing 'rag' in the middle. Note that, the filter condition for string value is case-sensitive.

use cases.example: bbox[0] + bbox[2] <= 100 and bbox[1] + bbox[3] <= 300 and pdf_id == '123456' and page_number == 1
use cases.description: For image modality, filter results to include only image regions that are entirely within the upper-left quadrant of page 1 in the PDF with ID '123456', assuming the page dimensions are 200 (width) x 600 (height).
